title: Project
text:
As an individual or in a team pick a topic and

create a (cleanish) dataset
choose an appropriate analysis
interpret results
publish your analysis and findings
Create a video highlighting your work

More information will be coming as we get closer to the start of the project work.

title: Screencast Checklist
text:
Screencast uploaded to YouTube/YuJa

If on YouTube, your screencast should be set so that anyone with the link can view the video.

Approximate time index provided for each of the 4 techniques youâ€™re demonstrating (examples) provided

in the README of your github repository
in the description of your video (if on YouTube)

Commented code for your screencast uploaded to the github repository

title: Working through code: data summaries
text:
#
# What is the average grade in each subject?
#
#   How many courses does each student take?
#
#   How many students are enrolled in total?

students <- data.frame(
  student_name = c("Alice", "Alice", "Bob", "Bob", "Alice", "Alice"),
  course = c("Math", "Science", "Math", "Science", "Math", "Science"),
  grade = c(85, 92, 78, 88, 82, 90),
  student_id = rep(1:3, each = 2)
)

library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4          âœ” readr     2.1.5     
âœ” forcats   1.0.0          âœ” stringr   1.5.1     
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2.9002     âœ” tibble    3.3.0     
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4          âœ” tidyr     1.3.1     
âœ” purrr     1.1.0          
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

duplicated(students |> select(student_id, course))

[1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE

students |> group_by(course) |>
  summarise(
    grade = mean(grade, na.rm=TRUE),
    n = n(),
    non_missing_grade = sum(is.na(grade))
  )

# A tibble: 2 Ã— 4
  course  grade     n non_missing_grade
  <chr>   <dbl> <int>             <int>
1 Math     81.7     3                 0
2 Science  90       3                 0

students |> group_by(student_id) |>
  summarise(
    num_courses = length(unique(course)),
    n = n(),
  ) |> ungroup()

# A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
  student_id num_courses     n
       <int>       <int> <int>
1          1           2     2
2          2           2     2
3          3           2     2

students |> summarize(
  num_enrolled = length(unique(student_id))
)

  num_enrolled
1            3

students |> count(student_id) |> nrow()

[1] 3

title: Outline
text:
Detection strategies


simple summary statistics




Data profiling - Automated scanning for patterns, anomalies, and quality issues
Statistical analysis - Outlier detection using z-scores, IQR, box plots
Rule-based validation - Business logic and constraint checking
Pattern matching - Regular expressions for format validation
Cross-field validation - Checking relationships between columns





Deletion - Remove rows/columns with missing values
Imputation - Fill with mean, median, mode, or predicted values
Forward/backward fill - Use previous/next valid values
Domain-specific rules - Business logic for missing value treatment
Flag creation - Create indicator variables for missingness





Format normalization - Consistent date formats, case, spacing
Value mapping - Standardize categories (â€œM/Fâ€ â†’ â€œMale/Femaleâ€)
Unit conversion - Consistent measurement units
Encoding standardization - UTF-8, consistent character sets
Naming conventions - Consistent column names and values





Exact matching - Remove identical records
Fuzzy matching - Similar records with slight differences
Key-based deduplication - Remove based on unique identifiers
Record linkage - Merge related duplicate entries
Master data management - Establish single source of truth





Type conversion - Ensure proper data types (numeric, date, categorical)
Schema validation - Verify structure matches expectations

Constraint enforcement - Check ranges, lengths, formats
Normalization - Split compound fields, remove redundancy





Outlier treatment - Remove, cap, or transform extreme values
Noise reduction - Smooth inconsistent measurements
Error correction - Fix typos, invalid entries
Enrichment - Add missing information from external sources
Validation against reference data - Check against authoritative sources

The key is applying these systematically and documenting all decisions for reproducibility.

title: 02-outlier-detection-and-mitigation
text:
library(VIM)
VIM::aggr(data)          # Missing data patterns
VIM::marginplot(data)    # Missing vs observed

library(corrplot)
corrplot(cor(data, use = "pairwise.complete.obs"))



library(outliers)
library(MVN)
# Multiple methods for identifying problematic observations

title: Homework 3: Flights across the US
text: Note: This assignment must be accepted in Canvas and submitted in github classroom.

title: Homework 3: Flights across the US
text:
Prepping

Accept the assignment in Canvas, follow the link to create a repository, and clone this repository to your local machine.
Create a file named index.qmd and add it to the repository. This is the file that should contain your code, results, and interpretations. Make sure to include enough detail that your work is fully reproducible.

title: Homework 3: Flights across the US
text:
To Do Items

Import flights for all three months into a single object flights. Report on the number of flights by months and the number of features reported for it.
Determine a key for the data set. Make sure to show that it fulfills the requirements of a key.
Give three different examples of transitive dependencies in the data.
Airport information is included for both Origin and Dest. Create a new data set called airports in which you include the information once, then remove all but the required airport information from the flights object.
Create a summary for the number of flights each day and plot it. Color the points by day of the week. Make sure to provide labels for the days of the week. Describe the general pattern for the number of flights you see. Which days do not follow this pattern?
The variable Cancelled contains information about whether a flight was cancelled. Why can we not assume that flight cancellations occur completely randomly? Identify at least two factors contributing to non-random flight cancellations and visualize your findings.

title: Homework 3: Flights across the US
text:
Submission
Ensure that the file index.qmd renders without errors. Read through the rendered document to check for consistency. Remove excessive printouts. Add all relevant(!) files to the repository, commit, and push!

title: Homework 1: Reproducibility
text:
Note: This assignment must be submitted in github classroom.


An example in reproducibility


This repository contains the Nebraskan subset from the 2023 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS). The BRFSS is run annually by the Center for Disease control and prevention (CDC).
You can load the data with
brfss <- readRDS("brfssNE2023.rds")
The dataset contains 12886 observations on 350 variables.
The codebook for the full data is available from https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/annual_data/annual_2023.html. A copy of the site is included in the repo in the file USCODE23_LLCP_021924.HTML.
Variables names starting with X_ in the R data are listed in the codebook without the starting X, i.e.Â the variable X_AGEG5YR can be found as _AGEG5YR in the codebook.


Todo

Clone this repository to your local machine and open RStudio using the file reproducibility-brfss.Rproj.
Create a quarto document index.qmd. This is the file in which you should include all of your work.
Use the brfss data described above to find an age distribution of all Nebraskans who participated in the BRFSS survey. Use the variable X_AGEG5YR and show the distribution in a barchart and a table. Make sure to address in a paragraph how you deal with non responses.

Is the age of Nebraskans distributed significantly different from the nationally reported age distribution? (You could run a Chi-square test of homogeneity using chisq.test) Make sure to interpret the results.
Re-do the analysis in questions 2 and 3 by considering the survey weights X_LLCPWT. Again, interpret the results. How do you explain the differences?



Submission

Make sure that your file index.qmd contains all the details needed for me to re-run your analysis.
Ensure that the file renders without an error.

Add your file index.qmd to the repository, commit and push.

title: 01-techniques
text:
1. Missing Data Methods
# Instead of just dropping missing values:
data_complete <- na.omit(data)  # ??? Loses information

# Use sophisticated imputation:
library(mice)  # Multiple imputation
library(VIM)   # Visualization of missing patterns
library(Hmisc) # Various imputation methods
Approaches: - Multiple imputation (MICE) - Maximum likelihood estimation
- Pattern-mixture models - Selection models


2. Robust Statistics
Methods that work well even with outliers/non-normal data:
# Robust alternatives to standard methods:
median(x)           # vs mean(x)
mad(x)              # vs sd(x) 
MASS::rlm()         # vs lm() - robust regression
robustbase::ltsReg() # least trimmed squares


3. Non-parametric Methods
When distributional assumptions fail: - Rank-based tests (Wilcoxon, Kruskal-Wallis) - Bootstrap and permutation tests - Kernel density estimation - Spline regression

title: Leftovers
text: â€œAnalysis of messy dataâ€ refers to the statistical methods and techniques specifically designed to handle data that violates the clean assumptions of standard statistical methods. This is different from â€œmessy data analysisâ€ (the process) - this is about the analytical techniques themselves.

title: Leftovers
text:
What Makes Data â€œMessyâ€ Statistically

Common Messy Data Problems:

Missing values (not at random)
Outliers and anomalies

Non-normal distributions

title: Leftovers
section: Best Practices for Messy Data Analysis
text:
Best Practices for Messy Data Analysis

1. Understand Your Messiness

Why is the data messy?
Is it measurement error, missing by design, or data quality issues?
Different causes require different solutions



2. Donâ€™t Rush to Clean

Sometimes the â€œmessâ€ contains important information
Missing patterns might be informative
Outliers might be your most interesting observations



3. Sensitivity Analysis

Try multiple approaches
See if conclusions are robust across methods
Document what changes and what doesnâ€™t



4. Model the Mess

Instead of cleaning first, model the messiness directly
Include missingness indicators as variables
Use hierarchical models for complex structure

What is messy data analysis
â€œMessy data analysisâ€ refers to the realistic, iterative, and often chaotic process of working with real-world data - as opposed to the clean, linear process often taught in textbooks.

title: Leftovers
text:
What Makes Data Analysis â€œMessyâ€

1. Non-linear Process

Analysis rarely goes: collect ??? clean ??? analyze ??? report
Instead: analyze ??? discover problems ??? go back ??? re-clean ??? re-analyze ??? repeat
Constant backtracking and revision



3. Unexpected Discoveries

Your hypothesis was wrong
The â€œsmoking gunâ€ variable is actually data entry errors
The interesting pattern disappears when you fix a bug

title: Leftovers
text:
Characteristics of Messy Analysis

Exploratory & Iterative

Start without knowing exactly what youâ€™re looking for
Follow interesting leads that emerge
Dead ends and false starts are normal



Problem-Driven

Questions evolve as you learn more about the data
Original research question often changes completely
Analysis shaped by whatâ€™s actually possible with your data



Tool-Switching

Excel for quick looks
R/Python for analysis

Back to Excel to check something
Maybe some SQL, maybe some manual inspection



Documentation Challenges

Hard to document a non-linear process
Your final clean code doesnâ€™t show the messy exploration
Reproducibility becomes complex

title: Leftovers
text:
Example of Messy Analysis Flow
1. Load data ??? discover 50% missing values
2. Investigate missingness ??? find it's not random
3. Research data collection ??? learn about system change in 2019
4. Split analysis by time period ??? find different patterns
5. Discover outliers ??? some are errors, some are real
6. Clean errors ??? realize you need domain expertise
7. Consult with subject matter expert ??? learn your assumptions were wrong
8. Start over with new understanding...

title: Leftovers
text:
Messy vs.Â Tidy
Hadley Wickhamâ€™s â€œTidy Dataâ€ principles help organize the technical structure, but even with tidy data, the analysis process remains messy:

Tidy data: Structured format for easier manipulation
Messy analysis: The human process of discovery and iteration

title: Leftovers
text:
Embracing the Mess

Good Practices:

Keep detailed lab notebooks/logs
Version control your code and data
Document dead ends (save future you time)
Expect to throw away lots of work
Separate exploration from final analysis scripts



Tools for Messy Work:

Jupyter notebooks for exploration
R Markdown for iterative analysis
Git for tracking changes
Informal plots and quick summaries
Collaborative tools for team messiness

title: Leftovers
text:
Why This Matters
Understanding that analysis is messy helps you: - Set realistic expectations for timelines - Budget time for exploration and dead ends - Communicate better with stakeholders about process - Feel normal when your analysis doesnâ€™t go smoothly - Design better workflows that accommodate messiness
Bottom line: Real data analysis is messy, iterative, and full of surprises. The goal isnâ€™t to eliminate the mess, but to manage it productively!
â€œMessy dataâ€ refers to real-world datasets that donâ€™t conform to the clean, structured format that statistical methods and analysis tools expect. Itâ€™s data that requires significant cleaning and preprocessing before analysis.

title: Leftovers
text:
Characteristics of Messy Data

1. Structural Issues

Multiple tables/sheets that should be combined
Variables stored in rows instead of columns (or vice versa)
Multiple variables crammed into one column
Headers and data mixed together

Example:
Messy format:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚        Sales Data 2023          â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ Q1: Jan=100, Feb=150, Mar=120   â”‚
â”‚ Q2: Apr=200, May=180, Jun=220   â”‚
â”‚ Total: 970                      â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

Should be:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ Month â”‚ Qtr â”‚ Sales   â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ Jan   â”‚ Q1  â”‚ 100     â”‚
â”‚ Feb   â”‚ Q1  â”‚ 150     â”‚
â”‚ Mar   â”‚ Q1  â”‚ 120     â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜


2. Data Quality Problems

Missing values (blanks, â€œN/Aâ€, â€œNULLâ€, -999, etc.)
Inconsistent formats (dates, currencies, addresses)
Typos and spelling variations (â€œNew Yorkâ€, â€œNYâ€, â€œnew yorkâ€)
Duplicate records
Outliers and impossible values (age = 150, negative prices)



3. Encoding Issues

Different data types in same column (numbers stored as text)
Character encoding problems (Ã± becomes ÃƒÂ±)
Mixed units (some measurements in feet, others in meters)
Inconsistent categories (â€œMale/Femaleâ€ vs â€œM/Fâ€ vs â€œ1/0â€)

title: Leftovers
text:
Common Sources of Messy Data

Human Data Entry
Expected:     Actual reality:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”  â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ Name â”‚Age â”‚  â”‚ Name â”‚ Age        â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤  â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ John â”‚ 25 â”‚  â”‚ John â”‚ 25         â”‚
â”‚ Mary â”‚ 30 â”‚  â”‚ mary â”‚ thirty     â”‚
â”‚ Bob  â”‚ 22 â”‚  â”‚ Bob  â”‚ 22 years   â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜  â”‚      â”‚ old        â”‚
               â”‚ Rob  â”‚ #N/A       â”‚
               â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜


System Integration

Data from multiple systems with different schemas
Legacy systems with outdated formats
APIs that change structure over time



Excel/Spreadsheet â€œFeaturesâ€

Merged cells
Formulas mixed with data

Multiple datasets in one sheet
Formatting used to convey meaning



Web Scraping

HTML tags mixed with content
Inconsistent page structures
Dynamic content that changes

title: Leftovers
text:
Examples of Messy Data

Wide Format (Should be Long)
Messy:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚ Country â”‚2019 â”‚2020 â”‚2021 â”‚2022 â”‚

title: Leftovers
text:
The Messy vs Tidy Spectrum
Extremely Messy: - PDF reports with embedded tables - Handwritten forms scanned as images - Audio/video that needs transcription
Moderately Messy: - Excel files with formatting and merged cells - CSVs with inconsistent column names - Databases with poor normalization
Slightly Messy: - Clean structure but some missing values - Consistent format but needs type conversion - Good data with a few outliers
Tidy: - Each variable in its own column - Each observation in its own row - Each cell contains a single value - Consistent missing value handling

title: Leftovers
text:
Tools for Handling Messy Data

R
library(tidyverse)  # dplyr, tidyr, stringr
library(janitor)    # clean_names(), get_dupes()
library(readxl)     # Excel files
library(VIM)        # Missing data visualization
library(OpenRefine) # GUI data cleaning


Python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import re  # Regular expressions
from fuzzywuzzy import fuzz  # String matching
import missingno as msno  # Missing data viz


Specialized Tools

OpenRefine: Interactive data cleaning
Trifacta/Alteryx: Commercial data prep tools
Excel Power Query: Built-in Excel cleaning tools

title: Leftovers
text:
Why Messy Data Matters

Reality Check

80% of data science is data cleaning
Real data is almost always messy
Textbook examples donâ€™t prepare you for reality



Business Impact

Bad data leads to bad decisions
Cleaning takes time and resources
Automation can help but isnâ€™t always possible



Statistical Validity

Messy data can bias results
Wrong conclusions from poorly cleaned data
Need to understand messiness to trust analysis

Bottom Line: Messy data is the norm, not the exception. Learning to identify, understand, and systematically clean messy data is one of the most practical skills in data analysis. The goal is transforming messy reality into tidy, analyzable datasets while preserving the valuable information buried in the mess!

text:
Cryptic Names
What are the variables? What are the observations?

More cryptic
Whatâ€™s in the column names of this data? What are the experimental units? What are the measured variables?

the experimental design is coded into the variable names, genotype:WI/WM, time:6/12, rep:1/2/4

title: What is â€œMessy Dataâ€?
text:
Gross on repeat
10 week sensory experiment, 12 individuals assessed taste of french fries on several scales (how potato-y, buttery, grassy, rancid, paint-y do they taste?), fried in one of 3 different oils, replicated twice.
First few rows:


# A tibble: 4 Ã— 9
  time  treatment subject   rep potato buttery grassy rancid painty
  <fct> <fct>     <fct>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>
1 1     1         3           1    2.9     0      0      0      5.5
2 1     1         3           2   14       0      0      1.1    0  
3 1     1         10          1   11       6.4    0      0      0  
4 1     1         10          2    9.9     5.9    2.9    2.2    0  


What is the experimental unit? What are the factors of the experiment? What was measured? What do you want to know?

title: Normal Forms of data
text:
Biological experiment
In a study, RNA-seq expressions of 11k different genes are measured at 6 and 12 hours after seeds from two different gene lines have germinated.
What is the key?

title: Normal Forms of data
text:
Weather station
A weather station publishes monthly averages for the minimum and maximum temperature during each hour of the day.
What is the key?

title: Normal Forms of data
text:
Tuberculosis
The World Health Organization track the number of new incidences of tuberculosis by sex and age group in each country.
What is the key?

title: Normal Forms of data
text:
French Fries
In a 10 week sensory experiment, 12 individuals assess taste of french fries on several scales (how potato-y, buttery, grassy, rancid, paint-y do they taste?), fried in one of 3 different oils, replicated twice.
What is the key?

title: Homework 1: Reproducibility
text:
Note: This assignment must be submitted in github classroom.


An example in reproducibility


This repository contains the Nebraskan subset from the 2023 Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS). The BRFSS is run annually by the Center for Disease control and prevention (CDC).
You can load the data with
brfss <- readRDS("brfssNE2023.rds")
The dataset contains 12886 observations on 350 variables.
The codebook for the full data is available from https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/annual_data/annual_2023.html. A copy of the site is included in the repo in the file USCODE23_LLCP_021924.HTML.
Variables names starting with X_ in the R data are listed in the codebook without the starting X, i.e.Â the variable X_AGEG5YR can be found as _AGEG5YR in the codebook.


Todo

Clone this repository to your local machine and open RStudio using the file reproducibility-brfss.Rproj.
Create a quarto document index.qmd. This is the file in which you should include all of your work.
Use the brfss data described above to find an age distribution of all Nebraskans who participated in the BRFSS survey. Use the variable X_AGEG5YR and show the distribution in a barchart and a table. Make sure to address in a paragraph how you deal with non responses.

Is the age of Nebraskans distributed significantly different from the nationally reported age distribution? (You could run a Chi-square test of homogeneity using chisq.test) Make sure to interpret the results.
Re-do the analysis in questions 2 and 3 by considering the survey weights X_LLCPWT. Again, interpret the results. How do you explain the differences?



Submission

Make sure that your file index.qmd contains all the details needed for me to re-run your analysis.
Ensure that the file renders without an error.

Add your file index.qmd to the repository, commit and push.

title: Your Turn code for normalizing data
text:
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

student_courses <- data.frame(
  student_id = c(101, 101, 102, 102, 103, 103),
  course_id = c("CS101", "MATH201", "CS101", "PHYS101", "MATH201", "CS101"),
  semester = c("Fall2023", "Fall2023", "Fall2023", "Fall2023", "Fall2023", "Fall2023"),
  instructor_name = c("Dr. Smith", "Dr. Johnson", "Dr. Smith",   "Dr. Johnson", "Dr. Brown", "Dr. Smith"),
  grade = c("A", "B+", "B", "A-", "A", "B+")
)

# We don't have duplicates:
!any(duplicated(student_courses))

[1] TRUE

student_courses |> count(student_id, course_id) |> filter(n > 1)

[1] student_id course_id  n         
<0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

student_courses |> count(student_id) |> filter(n > 1)

  student_id n
1        101 2
2        102 2
3        103 2

student_courses |> count(course_id) |> filter(n > 1)

  course_id n
1     CS101 3
2   MATH201 2

# yes, data set is in 1st normal form

courses <- student_courses |> group_by(course_id) |>
  summarize(
    semester = unique(semester),
    instructor_name = paste(unique(instructor_name), collapse=", ")
  )

!any(duplicated(courses$course_id))

[1] TRUE

title: Homework #1
text:
library(tidyverse)

â”€â”€ Attaching core tidyverse packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse 2.0.0 â”€â”€
âœ” dplyr     1.1.4          âœ” readr     2.1.5     
âœ” forcats   1.0.0          âœ” stringr   1.5.1     
âœ” ggplot2   3.5.2.9002     âœ” tibble    3.3.0     
âœ” lubridate 1.9.4          âœ” tidyr     1.3.1     
âœ” purrr     1.1.0          
â”€â”€ Conflicts â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidyverse_conflicts() â”€â”€
âœ– dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
âœ– dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
â„¹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(patchwork)


Load data, create index file
Load the data with

brfss <- readRDS("brfssNE2023.rds")



Find age distribution

age_table <- brfss |> group_by(X_AGEG5YR) |> summarise(
  frequency = n(),
  weighted = sum(X_LLCPWT2),
  raw_percent = n()/nrow(brfss)*100,
  weighted_percent = sum(X_LLCPWT2)/sum(brfss$X_LLCPWT2)*100
)

age_table |> knitr::kable(digits = 2)

# weighted frequencies are estimates for all of Nebraska

# shows frequencies, not a distribution
brfss |> ggplot(aes(x = X_AGEG5YR)) + geom_bar()







# from codebook: 
codebook <- data.frame(
  Value = 1:14, 
  Value_Label = c("Age 18 to 24", "Age 25 to 29", "Age 30 to 34", 
"Age 35 to 39", "Age 40 to 44", "Age 45 to 49", "Age 50 to 54", 
"Age 55 to 59", "Age 60 to 64", "Age 65 to 69", "Age 70 to 74", 
"Age 75 to 79", "Age 80 or older", "Don't know/Refused/Missing"
))

p1 <- brfss |> ggplot(aes(x = codebook$Value_Label[X_AGEG5YR])) + 
  geom_bar(aes(y = after_stat(count/sum(count)*100))) + coord_flip() + 
  ggtitle("Raw Percentages")

p2 <- brfss |> ggplot(aes(x = codebook$Value_Label[X_AGEG5YR], weight = X_LLCPWT2)) + 
  geom_bar(aes(y = after_stat(count/sum(count)*100))) + coord_flip() + 
  ggtitle("Weighted Percentages")

p1+p2









Non responses are included in the age distribution as a separate level.


Is the age of Nebraskans distributed significantly different from the nationally reported age distribution? (You could run a Chi-square test of homogeneity using chisq.test) Make sure to interpret the results.

National sample from the codebook:
Using ellmer with anthropic and prompt: â€œfrom the file at pathâ€USCODE23_LLCP_021924.HTMLâ€ in the working directory extract the table for _AGEG5YRâ€

# no need to run this over and over again, just create the data set once
# Load required libraries
library(rvest)

# Read the HTML file
html_content <- read_html("USCODE23_LLCP_021924.HTML")

# Extract all tables from the HTML
tables <- html_content %>% html_table(fill = TRUE)

# Look for the table containing _AGEG5YR
ageg5yr_table <- NULL
for(i in 1:length(tables)) {
  if(any(grepl("_AGEG5YR|AGEG5YR", tables[[i]], ignore.case = TRUE))) {
    ageg5yr_table <- tables[[i]]
    break
  }
}

write.csv(ageg5yr_table, "national-age.csv", row.names = FALSE)

Writing the result in a file and reading it back in:

national_age <- readr::read_csv("national-age.csv", skip = 2)

Rows: 14 Columns: 5
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (1): Value Label
dbl (3): Value, Percentage, Weighted Percentage
num (1): Frequency

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

national_age <- national_age |> mutate(
    `Value Label` = gsub("Age .*Notes: ", "", `Value Label`)
)
national_age <- national_age |> mutate(
    `Value Label` = ifelse(Value==14, NA, `Value Label`)
)
write.csv("national-age.csv", row.names=FALSE)

"x"
"national-age.csv"


Is there a difference between Nebraskansâ€™ ages and the national age distribution (based on the BRFSS sample)?

a1 <- age_table |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = X_AGEG5YR, y = raw_percent)) + 
  geom_point(aes(colour = "NE")) + 
  geom_point(aes(x = Value, y = Percentage, colour = "US"), data = national_age) + 
  ggtitle("Raw Percentages")

a2 <- age_table |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = X_AGEG5YR, y = weighted_percent)) + 
  geom_point(aes(colour = "NE")) + 
  geom_point(aes(x = Value, y = `Weighted Percentage`, colour = "US"), data = national_age) + 
  ggtitle("Weighted Percentages")
a1 + a2








The weighted percentages seem quite a bit different in the national sample, the raw percentages seem fairly similar

raw_frequencies <- data.frame(
  NE = age_table$frequency,
  US = national_age$Frequency
)

chisq.test(raw_frequencies)


    Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  raw_frequencies
X-squared = 157.1, df = 13, p-value < 2.2e-16

raw_percentages <- data.frame(
  NE = age_table$raw_percent,
  US = national_age$Percentage
)

chisq.test(raw_percentages)

Warning in chisq.test(raw_percentages): Chi-squared approximation may be
incorrect



    Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  raw_percentages
X-squared = 0.65857, df = 13, p-value = 1

weighted_percentages <- data.frame(
  NE = age_table$weighted_percent,
  US = national_age$`Weighted Percentage`
)

chisq.test(weighted_percentages)

Warning in chisq.test(weighted_percentages): Chi-squared approximation may be
incorrect



    Pearson's Chi-squared test

data:  weighted_percentages
X-squared = 3.3521, df = 13, p-value = 0.9963



# CramÃ©r's V (most common)
v1 <- sqrt(chisq.test(raw_frequencies)$statistic / nrow(brfss))

v2 <- sqrt(chisq.test(weighted_percentages)$statistic / 100)

Warning in chisq.test(weighted_percentages): Chi-squared approximation may be
incorrect

# Guidelines for CramÃ©r's V:
# Small: 0.1, Medium: 0.3, Large: 0.5



Submission

Make sure that your file index.qmd contains all the details needed for me to re-run your analysis.
Ensure that the file renders without an error.

Add your file index.qmd to the repository, commit and push.

title: Stat 471 - Analysis of Messy Data
text:
Fall 2025
TR 3:30 - 4:45 pm, Canvas
Office Hours: by appointment
Instructor: Heike Hofmann, hhofmann4 at unl dot edu



Course description

Analysis of complex, real-world data sets. Analysis techniques will vary depending on interest and availability of data sets.

Not all data lives in nice, clean spreadsheets, not all data fits in a computerâ€™s main memory. As statisticians we cannot always rely on other people and sciences to get the data into formats that we can deal with: we will discuss aspects of statistical computing as they are relevant for data analysis. Elements of literate programming help us with making our workflow transparent and analyses reproducible. We will discuss communication of results in form of web sites and interactive web applications.


Learn how to â€¦

compute with data to check the quality,
impute missing values, wrangle data formats, and join data sources.
write efficient and reproducible code so others are able to replicate the analysis.
pull data together to solve a contemporary problem.
use LLM bots to assess their helpfulness in different situations
publish reports on the web



More Info â€¦
The course organization on GitHub: https://github.com/stat471-at-UNL/stat471-at-UNL.github.io
Repo that creates this website: https://github.com/stat471-at-UNL/materials-2025

title: Project: Screencast
text:
Project Description
For your final project (which will take the place of the final exam), you will be recording a screencast in the style of David Robinsonâ€™s TidyTuesday screencasts.
You can find time-stamped, catalogued versions of some of David Robinsonâ€™s screencasts here.
Requirements:

Your screencast should be approximately 45 minutes long.
Your screencast should show your analysis of a TidyTuesday dataset from 2023
You should showcase at least 4 different techniques youâ€™ve learned in Stat 251. Some examples include:

data cleaning (dplyr) verbs
reshaping data (tidyr)
working with dates and times (lubridate)
working with strings (stringr)
writing functions to modularize your code
visualizing your data effectively


Unlike David Robinsonâ€™s screencasts, you will write a rough pseudocode â€œscriptâ€ before you start recording. This will give you a rough outline of how to do the analysis and what things you intend to cover.
Your goal is to help a future Stat 251 student understand some of the topics covered in this class. So while David Robinson and others who record their screencasts live might not fully explain what heâ€™s doing, you should take the time to explain each technique you decide to use in a way that will help someone else understand.
There will be three deliverables for this project:

Plan your dataset and topics
Pseudocode script uploaded to github repository
Screencast + github repository

Screencast uploaded to YouTube/YuJa
Approximate time index provided for each of the 4 techniques youâ€™re demonstrating (examples)
Code uploaded to github repository


In lieu of the final exam, you will peer review two classmatesâ€™ screencasts.
